elements.content: The coordination chemistry of the triazole-containing rigid crooked tetradentate ligands 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (L5) and 3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (L6) with inorganic Ag(I) salts has been investigated. Six new coordination polymers were prepared by solution reactions and fully characterized by infrared spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. {[Ag3(L5)2](NO3)3(H2O)4} n (1) (triclinic, P1̄; a = 6.9481(5) Å, b = 9.7267(6) Å, c = 12.8803(8) Å, α = 92.7760(10)°, β = 99.1170(10)°, γ = 104.4150(10)°, Z = 1) was obtained by the combination of L5 with AgNO3 in a H2O/CH3OH mixed solvent system, and features a unique two-dimensional sheet, which consists of large tetrameric and small dimeric rings. The approximate dimensions of the rings are ca. 23 × 6 Å and 4 × 8 Å, respectively. {[Ag3(L5)3](PF6)3·(H2O)·(CH3OH)} n (2) (monoclinic, P21 /n; a = 10.4641(6) Å, b = 15.6701(8) Å, c = 31.1907(17) Å, β = 94.8840(10)°, Z = 4) was generated from the reaction of L5 with AgPF6 in a H2O/CH3OH mixed solvent system. In 2, Ag(I) centers are interlocked together by L5 ligands through two terminal Npyridine and two Ntriazole donors into a novel noninterpenetrating three-dimensional framework with elliptical channels (effective cross-section of ca. 12.4 × 8.0 Å) extending along the crystallographic a axis. {[Ag(L5)](ClO4)·H2O} n (3) (triclinic, P1̄; a = 10.3605(16) Å, b = 10.5224(16) Å, c = 15.014(2) Å, α = 89.979(2)°, β = 76.656(2)°, γ = 89.980(2)°, Z = 4) was obtained by a combination of L5 with AgClO4 in a MeOH/H2O mixed solvent system. In the solid state, it forms a novel noninterpenetrating three-dimensional network with rhombic channels (effective cross-section of ca. 9.0 × 8.0 Å) along the crystallographic a axis, in which noncoordinated ClO4 - anions and H2O guest molecules are located. {[Ag(L6)](ClO4)·CH3OH} n (4) (monoclinic, C2/c; a = 14.1747(10) Å, b = 16.2713(11) Å, c = 15.9983(11) Å, β = 114.9410(10)°, Z = 8) was obtained by the combination of L6 with AgClO4 in a MeOH/H2O mixed solvent system. In the solid state, 4 features a novel noninterpenetrating three-dimensional framework with honeycomb-like and elliptical channels in two different crystallographic directions. Their dimensions are 8 × 7 and 18 × 4 Å, respectively. Uncoordinated ClO4 - counterions and MeOH guest molecules are located in these channels. {[Ag(L6)](PF6)·CH3OH} n (5) is generated from L6 and AgPF6 in a H2O/MeOH mixed solvent system and crystallizes in the space group C2/c, with a = 15.2035(10) Å, b = 16.5919(11) Å, c = 16.1240(10) Å, β = 116.8490(10)°, Z = 8. Compound 5 and 4 are isostructural. {[Ag2(C12H10N6)2](SiF6)·2H2O} n (6) (monoclinic, P21 /c, a = 11.3839(6) Å, b = 16.5163(8) Å, c = 7.4485(4) Å, β = 95.5450(10)°, Z = 2) was obtained by the combination of L6 ligand with AgSbF6 in a MeOH/H2O solvent system. In the solid state, compound 6 adopts a noninterpenetrating two-dimensional net. Uncoordinated SiF6 2- anions and water molecules are located between the layers and further linked by extensive H-bonding systems into a three-dimensional framework. When viewed down the crystallographic [101] direction, honeycomb-like channels were found, in which SiF6 2- counterions and water guest molecules are located.

elements.content: The coordination chemistry of the triazole-containing crooked rigid tetradentate ligands 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (L5) and 3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (L6) with inorganic Ag(I) salts has been investigated. Six new Ag(I)-containing coordination polymers were synthesized from solution reactions of L5−L6 with inorganic Ag(I) salts, respectively.

elements.content: The use of soluble inorganic transition metal ions or unsaturated transition metal coordination complexes and organic bidentate or multidentate ligands as precursors to organic/inorganic hybrid materials is a rapidly growing area of interest. For example, self-assembled coordination polymers with specific network topologies can provide highly ordered networks with different dimensionalities, particularly as two- or three-dimensional solids. Generally, some control over the type and topology of the product generated from the self-assembly of inorganic metal species and organic ligands can be achieved by careful choice of ligand, metal coordination geometry preference, inorganic counterion, solvent system, and metal salt-to-ligand ratio. Among these factors, the choice of the organic spacers is the single greatest influence in determining the type and topology of the product. Properties of organic spacers, such as solubility, coordination activity, length, geometry, and relative orientation of the donor groups, play a very important role in dictating polymer framework topology.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The use of soluble inorganic transition metal ions or unsaturated transition metal coordination complexes and organic bidentate or multidentate ligands as precursors to organic/inorganic hybrid materials is a rapidly growing area of interest. For example, self-assembled coordination polymers with specific network topologies can provide highly ordered networks with different dimensionalities, particularly as two- or three-dimensional solids. Generally, some control over the type and topology of the product generated from the self-assembly of inorganic metal species and organic ligands can be achieved by careful choice of ligand, metal coordination geometry preference, inorganic counterion, solvent system, and metal salt-to-ligand ratio. Among these factors, the choice of the organic spacers is the single greatest influence in determining the type and topology of the product. Properties of organic spacers, such as solubility, coordination activity, length, geometry, and relative orientation of the donor groups, play a very important role in dictating polymer framework topology.

elements.content: As we know, the rigid linear ligands, such as 4,4‘-bipyridine,1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene, 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)ethyne, and so on, have been the main theme in the chemistry of coordination polymers. All these bidentate N-donor containing ligands have proven to be among the most important types of organic ligands for the design and construction of coordination polymers exhibiting remarkable polymeric structural motifs. However, up to now, very little attention has been paid to the organic−inorganic coordination polymers or supramolecular complexes generated from bent organic ligands. We and others have been exploring the coordination chemistry based on oxadiazole-bridged bent organic ligands (Scheme ). As a result of the specific geometry of oxadiazole-containing ligands and the coordination preferences of transition metals, new types of coordination polymers, some with open channels and interesting luminescent properties, have been obtained. This encourages us to continue this project and expend oxadiazole-containing ligands to triazole-containing ligands. Herein, we wish to report six Ag-containing coordination polymers with novel polymeric motifs, namely, {[Ag3(L5)2](NO3)3(H2O)4} n (1), {[Ag3(L5)3](PF6)3·(H2O)·(CH3OH)} n (2), {[Ag(L5)](ClO4)·H2O} n (3), {[Ag(L6)](ClO4)·CH3OH} n (4), {[Ag(L6)](PF6)·CH3OH} n (5), and {[Ag2(L6)2](SiF6)·2H2O} n (6) generated from 3,5-disubstitued-4-amino-1,2,4-trizole ligands L5 and L6 (Scheme ) and inorganic Ag(I) salts.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. AgSO3CF3, AgNO3, AgClO4, AgPF6 (Acros) were used as obtained without further purification. L5 (2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) and L6 (2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) were prepared according to literature methods. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 400−4000 cm-1 range using a Perkin-Elmer 1600 FTIR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer model 2400 analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. AgSO3CF3, AgNO3, AgClO4, AgPF6 (Acros) were used as obtained without further purification. L5 (2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) and L6 (2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) were prepared according to literature methods. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 400-4000 cm-1 range using a Perkin-Elmer 1600 FTIR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer model 2400 analyzer.

elements.content:
Caution! Two of the crystallization procedures involve AgClO4, which is a strong oxidizer.

Preparation of {[Ag 3 (L5) 2 ](NO 3 ) 3 (H 2 O) 4 } n (1). A solution of L5 (4.76 mg, 0.020 mmol) in MeOH (10 mL) was layered onto a solution of AgNO3 (6.80 mg, 0.040 mmol) in H2O (10 mL). The solutions were left for about 3 days at room temperature, and colorless crystals were obtained. Yield, 78% (based on L5). Anal. Calcd. for C24H28Ag3N15O13 (1):  C, 27.22; H, 2.65; N, 19.84. Found:  C, 27.43; H, 2.60; N, 19.34. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3500(w), 3350(m), 3320(w), 1615(s), 1375(vs), 1530(w), 1481(w), 1307(vs), 1215(m), 834(s), 735(w).

elements.content: Single-Crystal Structure Determination. Suitable single crystals of 1−6 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. X-ray intensity data were measured at 150 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). The raw frame data for 1−6 were integrated into SHELX-format reflection files and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects using SAINT. Corrections for incident and diffracted beam absorption effects were applied using SADABS. None of the crystals showed evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Compound 1 and 3 crystallizes in the space group P1̄, compound 2 crystallizes in the space group P21 /n, compound 4 and 5 crystallize in the space group C2/c, and compound 6 crystallizes in the space group P21 /c, as determined by the pattern of systematic absences in the intensity data. All structures were solved by a combination of direct methods and difference Fourier syntheses and refined against F 2 by the full-matrix least squares technique. Crystal data, data collection parameters, and refinement statistics for 1−6 are listed in Tables and . Relevant interatomic bond distances and bond angles for 1−6 are given in Tables −8.

Corrections for incident and diffracted beam absorption effects were applied using SADABS. None of the crystals showed evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Crystal data, data collection parameters, and refinement statistics for 1-6 are listed in Tables  and . Relevant interatomic bond distances and bond angles for 1-6 are given in Tables -8.

Ligands and Synthesis of Compounds 1 − 5. L5 and L6 can be considered as new members of this five-membered heterocyclic ring bridging organic ligands. Compared to L1−L4, L5 and L6 are endowed with more structural information. For example, the 4-amino group on the trizole ring could serve as an additional coordinating donor, hydrogen bond acceptor, or donor. Moreover, it gives us a good chance to modify L5 and L6 to new organic spacers with novel geometries by some derivate reactions related to -NH2. L5 and L6 would be anticipated to exhibit more versatile coordination chemistry than L1−L4 by introducing the 4-amino-1,2, 4-triazole moiety.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Ligands and Synthesis of Compounds 1 - 5. L5 and L6 can be considered as new members of this five-membered heterocyclic ring bridging organic ligands. Compared to L1-L4, L5 and L6 are endowed with more structural information. For example, the 4-amino group on the trizole ring could serve as an additional coordinating donor, hydrogen bond acceptor, or donor. Moreover, it gives us a good chance to modify L5 and L6 to new organic spacers with novel geometries by some derivate reactions related to -NH2. L5 and L6 would be anticipated to exhibit more versatile coordination chemistry than L1-L4 by introducing the 4-amino-1,2, 4-triazole moiety.

elements.content: Compounds 1−6 were obtained as polymeric compounds in mixed solvent systems by the combination of L5 and L6 with different inorganic Ag(I) salts. It is worthwhile to point out that, in these specific reactions, the products do not depend on the ligand-to-metal ratio. However, increasing the metal-to-ligand ratio resulted in somewhat higher yield and higher crystal quality.
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1-6 were obtained as polymeric compounds in mixed solvent systems by the combination of L5 and L6 with different inorganic Ag(I) salts. elements.content: Structural Analysis. Structural Analysis of {[Ag 3 (L5) 2 ](NO 3 ) 3 (H 2 O) 4 } n (1). Crystallization of L5 with AgNO3 in methanol/water mixed solvent system at room temperature afforded the infinite two-dimensional sheet structure (1) in 78% yield. The metal-to-ligand ratio is 2:1 in the reaction. Single-crystal analysis revealed (as shown in Figure ) that there are two different Ag(I) centers in 1. The first Ag(I) center has linear coordination with the two Npyridyl atoms from two L5 ligands (N(1)−Ag(1)−N(1)#1 = 180.00(11)°, Ag(1)−N(1) = 2.117(3) Å). The second Ag(I) center, on the other hand, lies in a trigonal planar (sum of Ag−N angles = 355.7°) coordination environment, which consists of two Ntriazole donors (Ag(2)−N(2) = 2.240(2) and Ag(2)−N(3)#3 = 2.426(2) Å) from two L5 ligands and one Npyridyl donor (Ag(2)−N(6)#2 = 2.251(2) Å) from the third L5 ligand, respectively. The Ag−Ntriazole bond length is considerably longer than those of the Ag−Npyridyl bonds by 0.123−0.257 Å, but all Ag−N bond distances found in 1 are within the normal range observed in N-containing heterocyclic Ag(I) complexes. Each ligand is bound to four Ag(I) centers, including one Ag(1) and three Ag(2) centers. Two Ag(2) atoms are bridged by four Ntriazole atoms into a dinuclear core with a short Ag···Ag contact of 4.001(4) Å. The ligand itself is not planar. The corresponding dihedral angles between three rings are {N(1)- - -C(5)}−{N(2)- - -N(3)} = 59.3°, {N(1)- - -C(5)}−{N(6)- - -C(12)} = 30.5° and {N(2)- - -N(3)}−{N(6)- - -C(12)} = 34.8°.

elements.content: In the solid state, the Ag(1) and Ag(2) centers are linked together into a novel two-dimensional sheet, which is parallel to the [11̄1̄] plane. As shown in Figure , a single net consists of two different individual rings. The large one comprises a tetrameric unit, in which four Ag(I) centers are linked together by L5 ligands through both pyridyl and triazole N-donors into an elliptical 38-membered macrocycle. The approximate (crystallographic) dimension of the ring is 23 × 6 Å. The small one consists of a 14-membered dimeric unit. The effective cross-section is 4 × 8 Å. Surprisingly, no guest solvent molecules have been found in either the large or the small rings. These two-dimensional nets are not planar but undulating, which results from the crooked conformation of the ligand (Figure ). The crystal packing of 1 is shown in Figure . All the two-dimensional macrocycle-containing nets stack together along the crystallographic a axis and weak coordinated NO3 - counterions and water molecules are located between the interlayer space. Furthermore, amino nitrogen is hydrogen bonded to a water/nitrate disorder assembly (N(5)−H(5A)···O(12)#5:  d D - H = 0.88(3), d H ··· A = 2.08(4), d D ··· A = 2.957(4) Å, and <(DHA) = 172(3)°; O(31)−H(31B)···O(11)#6:  d D - H = 0.88(3), d(H···A) = 1.97(2), d(D···A) = 2.843(4) Å and <(DHA) = 168(4)°).

elements.content: Structural Analysis of {[Ag 3 (L5) 3 ](PF 6 ) 3 · (H 2 O) · (CH 3 OH)} n (2). To investigate the effect of the counterion on the long range order of the Ag(I)−L5 coordination polymer, the weakly coordinating PF6 - anion was used instead of the more strongly coordinating NO3 - anion. Crystallization of L5 with AgPF6 in a H2O/CH3OH mixed solvent system at room temperature afforded the infinite noninterpenetrating three-dimensional polymeric compound 2 in 73% yield. The metal-to-ligand ratio is 3:1 in the reaction. As shown in Figure , there are three independent Ag(I) centers, three L5 ligands, and three PF6 - anions in 2. All three crystallographic independent Ag(I) centers adopt a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere, which consists of two Npyridyl and two Ntriazole from four L5 ligands, respectively. The corresponding Ag(I)−Npyridyl and Ag(I)− Ntriazole bonding distances range from 2.248 to 2.489 and 2.263−2.337 Å, respectively. The Ag(I) and L5 connectivity has the -Ag−N−N−Ag−N−N- groupings, which is the same as observed in compound 1. The two Ag···Ag contacts in the Ag2N4 moieties are different. Ag(2)···Ag(3) contact is 4.066(5) Å, which is slightly longer than the Ag(1)···Ag(1) separation of 3.94(6) Å; however, it is almost identical to the Ag···Ag separation found in 1. In the solid state, Ag(I) centers are interlocked together by L5 ligands through two terminal Npyridine and two Ntriazole donors into a novel noninterpenetrating three-dimensional framework with elliptical channels (effective cross-section of ca. 12.4 × 8.0 Å)13 extending along the crystallographic a axis, in which the PF6 - counterions, disordered H2O, and CH3OH guest molecules are located (Figure ). The channel dimension is slightly smaller than that of the noninterpenetrating three-dimensional polymeric compound {[Ag(L3)]SO3CF3} n , wherein the similar rhombic channel was found. It is worthy to point out that silver atoms distribute in layers parallel to the crystallographic ac plane and H2O, CH3OH guest molecules and PF6 - anions arrange alternatively along the crystallographic b axis (Figure ). PF6 - anion, H2O and CH3OH guest molecules are bound by -NH2 groups on the framework through 14 sets of N···H−O and N−H···F hydrogen bonding systems, and the N···H and H···F distances are in the range of 2.16−2.55 and 2.09−2.59 Å, respectively (see Supporting Information).

elements.content: Structural Analysis of {[Ag(L6)](ClO 4 ) · CH 3 OH } n (3). The L5 ligand reacted with AgClO4 in H2O/C2H5OH at room temperature to produce the polymeric compound 3 with novel noninterpenetrating three-dimensional network in 72% yield. The X-ray structure of 3 shows that two independent Ag(I) centers in 3 (Figure ), and they both lie in a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere, which consists of two Npyridyl and two Ntriazole donors from two L5 ligands, respectively. The ligand here again acts as a tetradentate spacer toward these two independent Ag(I) ions. Compared to compound 2, the Ag(I)−Npyridyl bond lengths (2.246(4)−2.368(4) Å) are almost identical, whereas the Ag(I)−Ntriazole bond distances are remarkably elongated (2.310(4)−2.522(4) Å). This difference maybe is caused by the different templating effect of ClO4 - counterions and EtOH solvent molecules. As indicated in Figure , Ag(1) and Ag(2) centers distribute in layers parallel to the crystallographic ac plane, which is similar to that of 2. The Ag(I)···Ag(I) contact in the {Ag2N4} bimetallic ring is 3.814(3) Å, which is slightly longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii of two silver atoms, 3.44 Å. In the solid state, as shown in Figure , Ag(1) and Ag(2) atoms are linked to each other by L5 ligands via the {Ag2N4} moiety into a noninterpenetrating three-dimensional network, in which twisted hexagon channels with an effective cross-section of ca. 8.0 × 8.0 Å13 have been found. The channels extend along the crystallographic a axis, in which noncoordinated ClO4 - counterions and H2O solvent molecules are located. In addition, ClO4 - and H2O are seized together through O···H−O hydrogen bonding systems, furthermore, bounded to the framework through O···H−O and N···H−O interactions with the water and amino group hydrogen atoms (the distances between proton and nitrogen in the range of 2.02−2.24 Å).

elements.content: The coordination sphere of Ag(I) centers and coordination modes of ligand L5 in 2 and 3 are similar. As shown above, L5 acts as a tetradentate spacer toward Ag(I) ion, and all Ag(I) centers in 2 and 3 lie in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, which might be the reason to explain why compounds 2 and 3 adopt a similar topology. It is worthy to point out that the dihedral angles between two terminal pyridyl rings of L5 in 2 (68.2(4)°) and 3 (31.3(4)°) are different, which could result in the three-dimensional networks with different channels (elliptical channel in 2 and twisted hexagon channel in 3).

elements.content: Structural Analysis of {[Ag(L6)](ClO 4 ) · CH 3 OH } n (4). The idea behind the use of ligand L6 is to control supramolecular motifs through a 3,3‘-bipyridine-type ligand. It is well-known that the relative orientations of the nitrogen donors on the pyridyl rings and also the different bridging spacing might result in unusual building blocks, which can lead to the construction of supramolecular motifs that have not been achieved using normal rigid linear organic ligands. We earlier reported on a series of novel coordination polymers generated from rigid bidentate 4,4‘-bipyridine- and 3,3‘-bipyridine-type Schiff-base ligands. Indeed, our previous studies demonstrated that the relative orientations of the coordinating sites are one of the most important factors to control the polymeric motifs. On the other hand, our previous studies also demonstrated that the five-membered 1,3,4-oxadiazole bridged 3,3‘-bipyridine ligand could bind metal ions by cis or trans conformation and result in the framework topology versatile, sometimes even in affecting the formation of polymer vs molecule.

elements.content: Crystallization of L6 with AgClO4 in H2O/CH3OH at room temperature afforded a polymeric compound 4 with a novel noninterpenetrating three-dimensional network in 64% yield. The metal-to-ligand ratio is 3:1 in the reaction. There is only one kind of Ag(I) atom found in 4, which is different from that of in compounds 1−3. The asymmetric unit contains one Ag(I) atom, one L6 ligand, one ClO4 - anion, and one MeOH molecule of crystallization. As shown in Figure , the Ag(I) center lies in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment which consists of two Npyridine (N(1) and N(6)) and two Ntriazole (N(2) and N(3)) donors from four L6 ligands, respectively, with Ag−N bond distances from 2.2296(17) to 2.4118(17) Å. It is worth pointing out that L6 herein coordinates Ag(I) metal center in a transoid fashion (Figure ). Compared to 1−3, the same {Ag2N4} six-membered ring has been found. The corresponding Ag···Ag contact is 4.12(4) Å, which is slightly longer that those of 1−3. In the solid state, Ag(I) centers are connected to each other by crooked L6 ligands into a novel noninterpenetrating three-dimensional framework with channels in two different crystallographic directions. When viewed down the crystallographic a axis, almost regular honeycomb-like channels being filled with disordered MeOH guest molecules and ClO4 - counterions were found with the effective cavity size of ca. 8 × 7 Å (Figure ). It is interesting that all the amino groups on the triazole ring project into the channels and weakly hydrogen bond to the ClO4 - counterions. The assembly of honeycomb-like channels is challenging since the hexagon represents the one of the most common motifs in nature; however, synthetic noninterpenetrating three-dimensional networks with a honeycomb-like cross-section are still unusual, although some two-dimensional honeycomb-like nets have been previously obtained, such as [Ni(BTC)]3[BTC]2·14H2O·2C5H5N (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and [Ag(TCB)(CF3SO3)] (TCB = 1,3,5-tricyanobenzene). In the solid state, these two-dimensional nets stack in parallel and generate honeycomb-like channels. A interesting three-dimensional network, namely, ZnF(3-amino-1,2,4-triazole), was reported very recently. Similar regular honeycomb-like channels have been found. The channels have a 12 × 12 Å dimension that is larger than that of 4. To our knowledge, compound 4 reported herein is the first example of a noninterpenetrating three-dimensional honeycomb-like channel-containing network generated from crooked trizole-bridging tetradentate organic ligands. When viewed down the crystallographic [101] direction, elliptical channels were also found with the effective cavity size of ca. 18 × 4 Å (Figure ), in which disordered MeOH guest molecules and ClO4 - counterions are located. These disordered MeOH guest molecules are bound to the framework by a -NH2 group through six sets of N−H···O hydrogen bonding systems and the corresponding O···H distances lie in the range of 2.06−2.66 Å (see Supporting Information). Compared to 3, the channel pattern changes from an anomalous hexagon in 3 to a regular hexagon in 4, indicative of the remarkable influence of the different orientations of the nitrogen donors on the pyridyl rings.

elements.content: Structural Analysis of {[Ag(L 6 )](PF 6 ) · CH 3 OH} n (5). Crystallization of L6 with AgPF6 in H2O/CH3OH at room temperature afforded a polymeric compound 5 with a novel noninterpenetrating three-dimensional network in 61% yield. The asymmetric unit consists of the Ag(I) center, one L6 ligand, one PF6 - anion disordered over two orientations in the refined ratio 0.631(5)/0.369(5), and one methanol molecule of crystallization disordered equally over two orientations. Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that the local coordination geometry of the Ag(I) center in compound 5 (Figure ) is similar to that of compound 4. The Ag−N bond lengths lie in the range of 2.249(2)−2.381(2) Å, which are comparable to those of corresponding bond distances found in 4. Compared to 1−4, the same {Ag2N4} connectivity has been found with a Ag···Ag contact of 4.19(3) Å. Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compounds 4 and 5 are isostructural, and for compounds 4−5, there is an interesting change in the unit cell parameters upon increasing the counterion size from ClO4 - to PF6 -. The cell volume increases as expected, but does so in an anisotropic way. In the solid state, compound 5 adopts the same noninterpenetrating three-dimensional network as found in compound 4. Honeycomb-like channels contain distorted PF6 - counterions and MeOH solvent molecules. Those channels extend in two different directions (a and c axes) that are shown in Figure . Again, PF6 - counterions and MeOH guest molecules are fixed by five sets of hydrogen bonding systems, and the corresponding O···H and F···H distances are in the ranges of 1.90−2.21 and 2.26−2.46 Å, respectively (see Supporting Information). As shown in Figure , channels in 5 extend along the crystallographic a and c axes, respectively. The corresponding channel dimensions are almost identical with those of 4.

elements.content: Structural Analysis of {[Ag 2 (C 12 H 10 N 6 ) 2 ](SiF 6 ) · 2H 2 O} n (6). Crystallization of L6 with AgSbF6 in H2O/CH3OH at room temperature afforded a polymeric compound 6 with a novel noninterpenetrating two-dimensional network in 64% yield. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compound 5 crystallizes in the space group P21 /c as uniquely determined by the pattern of systematic absences in the intensity data. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ag(I) atom, one L6 ligand, a water molecule, and half of a SiF6 2- anion located on an inversion center. As shown in Figure , the Ag(I) center lies in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, which consists of two terminal Npyridyl donors from two L6 ligands and two Ntriazole donors from the other two L6 ligands, respectively. The Ag−N bond lengths lie in the range of 2.327(2)−2.382(2) Å, which are comparable to those of corresponding bond distances found in 1−5. It is worth pointing out that the L6 ligand in 6 adopts a cisoid conformation of the two terminal pyridyl rings to bind Ag(I) atoms, versus transoid for compounds 4 and 5 (Figure ). Again there is the {Ag2N4} metallacycle in which the Ag···Ag contact is 4.38(2) Å, which is comparable of those in compound 1−5. It is worth noting that the counterion in 6 found is SiF6 2- instead of SbF6 -, which was used initially as starting material in the reaction. It is well-known that BF4 -, PF6 -, and other fluoro anions can hydrolyze in the presence of moisture to release HF and F-, and these species can attack the glassware (in this case, the vial used for the reaction) and leach silicon atom from glass, eventually forming SiF6 2- counterions. To confirm this interesting reaction, AgBF4 was used instead of AgSbF6 to perform the same reaction under the same reactive conditions; as a result, compound 6 was obtained again which was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and also elemental analysis.

elements.content: In the solid state, Ag(I) centers are connected to each other by tetradentate L6 ligands into a novel two-dimensional net parallel to the crystallographic bc plane (Figure ). The two-dimensional net consists of three different kinds of metallacyacles, i.e., big ellipse-like binuclear, medium rectangle-like binuclear, and small rhombus-like binuclear metallacycles. The crystallographic dimensions13 are 12.16 × 5.37, 5.74 × 3.23, and 3.35 × 2.34 Å, respectively. SiF6 2- anions and water molecules are located between these layers and hydrogen bond these two-dimensional nets through N−H···F, O−H···N, N−H···O, and N−H···N hydrogen bonding systems into a three-dimensional framework (Figure ). The corresponding hydrogen bond distances and angles are listed in Table . When viewed down the crystallographic [101] direction, honeycomb-like channels were found, in which SiF6 2- counterions and water guest molecules are located (Figure ).

In general, the combination of tetrahedral Ag(I) or Cu(I) centers with rigid linear bidentate ligands generally result in the adamantoid structure. In 1−6, however, the crooked geometry of the ligands of L5−L6 and also the coordination of the Ntriazole donors result in the formation of this unique two- or three-dimensional network instead of the adamantoid framework.

elements.content: Luminescent Properties of L5 − L6, 1 − 2, and 4 − 5. Inorganic−organic hybrid coordination polymers have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Owing to the ability of affecting the emission wavelength of organic materials, syntheses of inorganic−organic coordination polymers by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials. We have been exploring the luminescent properties of L1−L2 and organic/inorganic coordination polymers and supramolecular complexes based on them in the solid state. The results indicate that emission colors of organic spacers L1 and L2 were remarkably affected by their incorporation into metal-containing coordination compounds. The luminescent properties of L5−L6 and polymeric compounds 1−2 and 4−5 were investigated in the solid state. The fluorescence spectra of L5 and 1−2 are shown in Figure . As indicated in Figure , L5 exhibits one emission maximum at 375 nm, with a second, less intense band present at 397 nm. For compounds 1 and 2, the maximum emission bands are blue-shifted to 366 and 365 nm, respectively; however, no enhancement of the fluorescence intensity is realized. For L6, as shown in Figure , the emission maximum is present at 373 nm, with a second, much less intense band present at 368 nm. The emission color of 4, compared to L6, is blue-shifted to 363 nm. As shown in Figure , compound 5 undergoes a blue-shift from 373 and 368 nm to 368 and 350 nm, respectively. Overall, free L5 and L6 were significantly affected by its incorporation into the Ag(I)-containing polymeric compounds, as evidenced by the large shift in the emission.
elements.clean_text: Luminescent Properties of L5 - L6, 1 - 2, and 4 - 5. Inorganic-organic hybrid coordination polymers have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Owing to the ability of affecting the emission wavelength of organic materials, syntheses of inorganic-organic coordination polymers by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials. We have been exploring the luminescent properties of L1-L2 and organic/inorganic coordination polymers and supramolecular complexes based on them in the solid state. The results indicate that emission colors of organic spacers L1 and L2 were remarkably affected by their incorporation into metal-containing coordination compounds. The luminescent properties of L5-L6 and polymeric compounds 1-2 and 4-5 were investigated in the solid state. The fluorescence spectra of L5 and 1-2 are shown in Figure . As indicated in Figure , L5 exhibits one emission maximum at 375 nm, with a second, less intense band present at 397 nm. For compounds 1 and 2, the maximum emission bands are blue-shifted to 366 and 365 nm, respectively; however, no enhancement of the fluorescence intensity is realized. For L6, as shown in Figure , the emission maximum is present at 373 nm, with a second, much less intense band present at 368 nm. The emission color of 4, compared to L6, is blue-shifted to 363 nm. As shown in Figure , compound 5 undergoes a blue-shift from 373 and 368 nm to 368 and 350 nm, respectively. Overall, free L5 and L6 were significantly affected by  its incorporation into the Ag(I)-containing polymeric compounds, as evidenced by the large shift in the emission.

elements.content: This study demonstrates that the triazole-containing rigid organic ligands 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (L5) and 3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (L6) are capable of coordinating metal centers with both Npyridyl and Ntriazole donors, and generate novel coordination polymers. Six new polymeric compounds 1−6 were synthesized from solution reactions of L5 and L6 with various Ag(I) salts. The relative orientation of the nitrogen donors on the pyridyl rings and the five-membered triazole spacing in L5 and L6 resulted in unusual building blocks, leading to the construction of polymeric motifs, which have not been obtained using normal linear rigid bidentate organic ligands, such as 4,4‘-bipy and related organic spacers. We are currently extending this result by preparing new triazole-containing ligands of this type containing different coordination functional groups and having different orientations of the nitrogen donors on the pyridyl rings. We anticipate that this new type of organic ligand will result in a variety of new coordination polymers with novel polymeric patterns.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

This study demonstrates that the triazole-containing rigid organic ligands 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (L5) and 3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (L6) are capable of coordinating metal centers with both Npyridyl and Ntriazole donors, and generate novel coordination polymers. Six new polymeric compounds 1-6 were synthesized from solution reactions of L5 and L6 with various Ag(I) salts. The relative orientation of the nitrogen donors on the pyridyl rings and the five-membered triazole spacing in L5 and L6 resulted in unusual building blocks, leading to the construction of polymeric motifs, which have not been obtained using normal linear rigid bidentate organic ligands, such as 4,4‘-bipy and related organic spacers. We are currently extending this result by preparing new triazole-containing ligands of this type containing different coordination functional groups and having different orientations of the nitrogen donors on the pyridyl rings. We anticipate that this new type of organic ligand will result in a variety of new coordination polymers with novel polymeric patterns.
